title: Mice and men
subject_group: Food, Health, Lifestyle, Medicine, Psychology & Safety/Aggressiveness (Psychology)
Climate, Environment, Natural Resources & Disasters/Natural history
Food, Health, Lifestyle, Medicine, Psychology & Safety/Social psychology
Economics, Philosophy, Politics, Religion & Sociology/Social psychology

Economics, Philosophy, Politics, Religion & Sociology/Social control
description: Examines differing social patterns of mice and insects, and indicates similarities between mice and men. Discusses instinctive behaviour, relationships, social dominance and how man's intervention can alter this dominance. Looks also at aggression and the prevention of unlimited aggression. Spoken by Brian Inglis and Bob Holness. Suitable for upper secondary level.
